H0.text: Pollution was the most likely factor that contributed to the extinction of native animal species when humans first began to grow crops.

H1.text: Climate change is the most likely factor that contributed to the extinction of native animal species when humans first began to grow crops.

H2.text: Habitat destruction most likely contributed to the extinction of native animal species when humans first began to grow crops.

H3.text: Tectonic plate motion most likely contributed to the extinction of native animal species when humans first began to grow crops.

A4.text: Habitat destruction is in fact the leading cause of biodiversity loss and species extinction worldwide.

A5.text: Conversion to 'trivial' standardized ecosystems (e.g., monoculture following deforestation) effectively destroys habitat for the more diverse species.
